history.content:
I'm in CS 170 right now, but I'll tell you a little about my experiences in the past with this kind of thing. I've been in similar situations to yours multiple times, and honestly trying to calculate the bare minimum you need to get a grade you want is never going to help you succeed. I know it sounds corny, and I'm sure you've heard this before, but you should always aim to do the best you can. Don't think that it's impossible to do well enough to recuperate from your losses, because countless people have done it before you and will continue to do it and so can you. The most important thing to do is to find ways to learn the material so deeply that you can answer any type of question that comes your way. Whether this involves doing countless practice problems or working with peers to help each other learn, you need to do whatever it takes to be as confident as you possibly can come test day that you will do well on the test. Worrying about what exact score you need to get a B+ is only going to bog you down, and honestly "one standard deviation above mean" means absolutely nothing until you know what's actually on the test. Z-score is one of those things that hides the truth behind the test like what was actually tested.
A more concrete answer to your question is probably around 1 sd above mean, but honestly no one can actually answer this question until all the scores are in and the professors decide the curve. The real answer to how well you need to do to get the grade you want is, of course, as well as you possibly can.

children.subject:
I got a 47% on both CS70 midterms (about 1 SD below the mean). During Dead week, I studied my butt off by taking about three practice tests - but I have a particular strategy for pratice tests - I attempt every question on my own first, and then after attempting all (and giving myself a reasonable amount of time to think about ones I was stuck on but not forcing myself to sit there for hours), and then thoroughly correcting the test. For every question i got wrong, I tried to figure out why my answer was wrong and why the official solution was right. For every question I left blank, I tried to understand the solution and figured out what line of thinking would have led me to be unstuck during an exam ("Oh you were trying to prove the forward implication but it was actually much easier to prove the contrapositive"). And then if I didn't understand the official solution I would sit in office hours until I did. With that, I ended up doing about +0.7 above the mean on the final. And I ended up with a B+ in the course overall. 

Slight caveat: the final covered some matieral I had seen before, but I still struggled with it. 

This deals with 70, not 170, but I hoped to provide some perspective on how I turned my semester around. 

Also keep in mind that oftentimes the final has a focus on the last third of the course, which hasn't been tested yet, and you may turn out to be better at that material!

Hey, OP, a late followup, but I was wondering how you did on the final and what grade you ended up with in the course? I'm in a similar situation this semester, having been ~0.5 SD below mean on both midterms, and above average (nearly 100%) on the HWs. I see that the curve for Fall 2018 was really lenient compared to past semesters, with even the 35th percentile getting a B+, but was wondering how you did and how you managed to get out of the slump (if you did).

history.content: Wondering if anyone has had any success stories with CS170 in the past. Currently doing around 0.5 SD's below on both midterms but aiming for a B+ or higher in the class. How would I have to do on the final?
history.subject: Success stories with CS170?
